title: 2025 Bonteheuwel Development Tournament
content: Bonteheuwel — the place where Steinitz Chess Club first took shape — came alive again as Steinitz Club President Andrew Talmarkes organised the inaugural development tournament. It was a full-circle moment for a club built on both excellence and opportunity, proving once more that true champions never forget their roots.

title: 2025 Royal Rapid Challenge
content:
The Royal Alphas club was formed in 2025 by former youth members of Elsies River club. Their inaugural tournament took place at the UWC Sports Hall and was a resounding success - despite some initial noise-related challenges! Our Steinitz players brought home several accolades:
Ethan Samuels - 1st in the A-section. Ashley Schuller - Best Senior in the A-section. Furqaan Bowman - 1st in the B-section & best Junior in the B-section. Colin Webber - Best Senior in the B-section. Also participating in the A-section were Benjamin Dubbeld and Alex Akemdien.
Note
Photos courtesy of Flashlight Pictures and Andrew Talmarkes.

title: 1991 - no result
1992 - 1st non-racial/unified league
content: Shaun Willenberg vs Unknown, circa ‘92-‘94.

Steinitz A-team, from front to back, left to right: Kenny Willenberg, Craig Willenberg, Lyndon Bouah, Mark Lewis, Denise Bouah, Glenn Willenberg, Andreas De Jager, Luan De Jager, Michael James, Ethan Samuels, Andrew Talmarkes.
Steinitz A-team, from left to right: Andrew Talmarkes, Andreas De Jager, Ethan Samuels, Lyndon Bouah, Luan De Jager, Craig Willenberg, Ashley Schuller, Kenny Willenberg, Glen Willenberg.

title: 2025 CTCF Club League
content:
The 2025 CTCF Club League is Cape Town’s premier team chess competition, bringing together the region’s strongest clubs in an 11-round tournament played over three months. The league showcases both established masters and rising talents, fostering competitive spirit and community among local players. With the season still underway, every round remains crucial as teams battle for top honors and bragging rights in one of South Africa’s most prestigious club events. Note
Most of the tournament photos from rounds 1-8 were captured by Naomi Bolton of Helderberg Photography. Support her by contributing just R10 towards the development of the amazing ClashOTB app!
Round 11 Round 10 Round 9 Rounds 7-8 Rounds 5-6 Rounds 3-4

title: 2025 Hermanus Chess Club Open
content: Hermanus Chess Club hosted it’s annual open on a rainy April day. However, multiple Steinitz players shone brightly, bringing home medals and trophies in all divisions.

title: Evaluate before you Calculate!
description: Positional Insight: The Four Key Elements
content:
Positional Insight: The Four Key Elements Positional insight is gained by applying four key elements to any position. These universal elements will improve your calculation process once fully grasped. Don’t rush to calculate lines—first aim to understand the situation.
The Elements King Safety & Activity Pawn Structure Piece Activity (center control & space) Material Chess is fundamentally positional before it is tactical. Tactically rich and creative play grows out of sound positional understanding.
“Masterpieces cannot create themselves, but rather come from long-term vision and the ability to coordinate your army effectively.”
— CM Kenneth Willenberg
1. King Safety & Activity Short- and long-term understanding of this element develops with practice until it becomes second nature.
Opening/Middlegame: King safety must be a top priority; with many pieces still on the board, an exposed king is vulnerable. Endgame: King activity becomes critical. A centralized king can be worth up to four tempi in the endgame as a fighting piece. 2. Pawn Structure Pawns are the soul of chess—they give the game its frame and structure. Weak pawns become targets, especially in endgames.
Maintain a healthy, connected structure and claim space when justified. A pawn on the seventh rank ready to promote is worth more than a mere one point. Value passed pawns, and prepare pawn breaks. Always place pawns with the endgame in mind. 3. Piece Activity & Comparing Piece Power Question every piece’s impact on the position and its prospects for creating play. Compare each of your pieces with your opponent’s to find their true worth and contribution to the battle.
4. Material Beginners and intermediate players often over-prioritize material. Mastery reveals that chess is less about static material and more about a piece’s effectiveness in a given situation and its dynamic potential.
Compensation over material: Activity, space, and development can outweigh nominal value. A bishop can be more effective than a rook; a rook and knight can outplay a queen with the right coordination. Material is therefore the last element in assessing positions. Over time, this ordering should become second nature. Play for positional value and you’ll create rich, exciting positions with well-coordinated plans.
How to Improve Your Evaluation Skills Practice Analyze games—your own and those of stronger players—paying attention to how positions are evaluated and why certain plans were chosen.
Study Learn common strategic themes: pawn-structure weaknesses, king safety, piece activity, outposts, space, and key files/diagonals.
Use Chess Engines (Wisely) Use engines to analyze positions and compare your evaluations to theirs. Focus on understanding why a move is strong, not just the numerical score.
How Do GMs Do It? (Universality of Method) Grandmasters evaluate positions by quickly assessing the critical factors—material balance, king safety, piece activity, center control, and pawn-structure integrity—and then prioritizing what matters most in this position right now.
Key checkpoints:
Material Balance: Rapidly gauge who stands up or down and what trades favor your plan. King Safety: Identify vulnerabilities; a weak king can override other advantages. Piece Activity: Ensure every piece has a role and targets; improve the worst-placed piece. Center Control: Control of central squares enables mobility and attacks. Pawn Structure: Spot weaknesses (isolated, doubled, backward pawns) and potential breaks. Time Management: Factor in the clock; practical decisions matter under pressure. Plan: Evaluate the board in terms of your current plan and the moves that advance it. Forcing Moves: Always scan for checks, mate threats, captures, threats to win material, and moves that force a specific response.

title: 2025 Cape of Good Hope
content: The Cape of Good Hope Chess Championships was hosted by Cape Town Chess Federation and took place on 22 & 23 February 2025 at the Western Cape Sport School in Kuilsriver.

title: 2024 CTCF Club League
content: Our Steinitz A-team won silver in the Premier Division of the 2024 CTCF Club League Championship.

title: 2024 Steinitz Festival
content: The 47th anniversary Steinitz Chess Festival took place at Fairbairn College, Goodwood. 250 players participated with various Junior age groups, rapid sections, Fide rated sections. Players came from as far afield as Namibia, KZN and Mossel Bay, Overberg.

title: 2024 Club Championship
content: The 2024 Annual Steinitz Chess Club Championship took place in Cape Town on Saturday, April 13th, 2024. The event featured six rounds played at a rapid time control of 20 minutes plus a 5-second increment per move. Bringing together a strong field of club members, the championship provided an exciting day of competitive chess, highlighting both seasoned players and rising stars within the Steinitz community.

title: 2024 SA Senior Closed
content:
The 2024 SA Senior Closed at the iconic Newlands venue was a fiercely contested and well-organized event, ending with Dr Lyndon Bouah and FM Shabier Bhawoodien sharing the senior title in a fitting display of competitive balance and sporting tradition.
Day 1

title: 2022 CTCF Club League
content:
Congratulations to our Steinitz A-team for winning the Premier Division of the 2022 Chess WP Club League Championship! We also congratulate Kraaifontein (winners of B Division), Capablanca (winners of C Division) and Delft (winners of D Division).
Steinitz A-team, from left to right: Andrew Talmarkes, Andreas De Jager, Ethan Samuels, Lyndon Bouah, Luan De Jager, Craig Willenberg, Ashley Schuller, Kenny Willenberg, Glen Willenberg.
Kraaifontein A-team - winners of the B Division.
Capablanca A-team - winners of the C Division.
Delft A-team - winners of the D Division.

title: Reflections on the 2019 Cape Town Club League
description: Steinitz Chess Club has won the Chess Western Province 2019 league in superlative fashion.
content:
Reflections on Steinitz in the WP League When I look back at the 2019 Western Province League, I feel immense pride in what Steinitz Chess Club has achieved. Over the course of that season, we played 11 matches, winning 10 and drawing just one — against a strong MRL side. Not once did we taste defeat. That kind of consistency doesn’t happen by accident. It reflects years of teamwork, preparation, and commitment.
A run of dominance Our unbeaten streak stretched well beyond 2019. In fact, over three years of competitive play — between 2017 and 2019 — Steinitz played 46 classical matches without losing a single one. Every time we sat down at the board, I felt the weight of that record, but also the confidence of being part of a team that simply refused to yield.
In 2017, during the Western Province Club Championship (played in early 2018), we swept the field with six wins from six.
In 2018, our league campaign was just as steady — 11 matches played, 8 wins and 3 draws against tough sides like Blackjacks, ACL and Stellenbosch. We followed that up by winning the Western Cape Club Championship, once again with a perfect 6/6.
And in 2019, we carried the torch even higher. Not only did we win the WP League, but we also went on to claim both the Western Cape Club Championship and the South African Club Championship, winning every single match in those events. To dominate provincially and then replicate that at national level was something special.
Individual performances What made Steinitz so formidable was not just one or two stars, but the depth of our squad. I recall:
Kenneth Willenberg on board one, scoring 5/6 against the strongest opposition. On board two, I myself managed a perfect 6/6, something I’ll always treasure. Luan De Jager on board four was rock solid, finishing 4/4. Glenn Willenberg impressed on board five with 4.5/5. These kinds of performances showed the strength in depth we had — every player contributing, every point hard-earned.
What it meant For me, Steinitz has always been more than just a chess club. I first played for Steinitz back in 1996, and since then I’ve played over 200 classical matches in its colours. To see the club reach such heights in recent years has been personally fulfilling, but also a testament to what collective dedication can achieve. We weren’t just winning matches; we were building a culture of excellence, camaraderie and resilience.
When you go three years without losing a match, you set a standard. That standard now lives in every Steinitz player, old and new. It is a reminder that our best days aren’t behind us — they are part of an ongoing tradition of striving, improving, and inspiring.
Looking forward As I reflect on those seasons, I am grateful to my teammates, the Steinitz committee, and the broader chess community that has supported us. Success is never individual — it is shared. And at Steinitz, we share not just the victories, but also the commitment to keep the flame burning for the next generation.

title: 2019 CTCF Club League
content: Our Steinitz A-team won gold in the Premier Division of the 2019 CTCF Club League Championship.

title: 2014 AfriClub Champs
content: In March 2014, Cape Town proudly hosted the prestigious African Club Chess Championship at the Sun Hotel. The event brought together top club teams from across the continent, showcasing Africa’s finest chess talent in a spirit of competition and camaraderie. Players battled over the boards in a festival of strategy and skill, while the Mother City provided a fitting backdrop with its vibrant culture and iconic scenery. The tournament not only highlighted the growing strength of African chess but also reinforced Cape Town’s reputation as a hub for international sporting events.

title: Alex Akemdien
content: Alex Akemdien is a rising talent in the chess world, known for his sharp tactical vision and calm approach under pressure. He began playing chess at a young age and quickly distinguished himself on the local circuit, earning recognition for his rapid improvement and consistent performances against seasoned opponents. Over the years, Alex has represented his club in multiple regional and national tournaments, where he has delivered notable results on top boards. His ability to combine creative attacking play with solid strategic understanding has made him a formidable competitor. Beyond individual accolades, Alex has contributed significantly to his team’s success, helping secure podium finishes in league competitions. Dedicated to continual growth, he studies classical games and modern opening theory with equal enthusiasm, ensuring his style remains both dynamic and adaptable. With his ambition and discipline, Alex Akemdien is steadily building a reputation as one of the promising chess players to watch in the coming years.

title: Andre Fortune
content: Andre Fortune is a long-standing member of the Steinitz Chess Club in Cape Town and a regular at the club’s games and league matches. Like his father Ivan, he plays with solid competence and enthusiasm — not a player chasing major tournament victories, but very much one who values the board, the community, and steady improvement over time. Though André has not, in public sources, been credited with high-profile tournament wins, he has featured in numerous club league games as part of Steinitz and regularly competes alongside peers of similar strength. His rating (as listed on club membership listings) places him near the intermediate level among the membership at Steinitz. In all his years of involvement, what stands out about Andre is his consistency: he shows up for club get-togethers, participates in matches, plays casual games with new and old members alike, and contributes to the friendly yet competitive atmosphere that helps keep the club alive. He demonstrates sportsmanship, patience, and a willingness to learn from each game, whether it ends in win, loss or draw. Outside of matches, Andre is part of the broader tapestry of Steinitz: sharing in its history, its social evenings, mentoring newer players by example, and being part of Steinitz’s identity as a club where chess is as much about community as competition.

title: Andrew Talmarkes
content:
Andrew Talmarkes is an accomplished chess coach, FIDE-licensed arbiter, and long-time leader within Cape Town’s Steinitz Chess Club. He is the Director of the Insight Chess Academy, providing specialized individual and group coaching—including tailored sessions for clients with ADHD or focus challenges.
A pillar in chess administration, he has served in numerous key roles including tournament director and deputy chief arbiter for numerous national tournaments. He is also a fixture within the CHESSA development arbiter program as well as the Western Province youth coaching scene. Awarded the Community Builder Award in 2013 for his work on Mitchell’s Plain Chess Development and Library Project, Talmarkes continues to shape youth and community chess.

title: Andrew Talmarkes
content:

title: Benjamin Dubbeld
content: Benjamin Dubbeld is a promising young chess player from Cape Town. Introduced to competitive chess in grade 8 at Westerford High School in 2023, he quickly developed a love for the game and began participating in local tournaments in 2024. Now in grade 10, Benjamin is a key member of his school’s first team, contributing to their successes in interschool competitions. His strong performances have earned him selection for the Western Province Under-18 team, which will compete in Gqeberha in December. Benjamin combines a strategic approach with keen tactical awareness, showing steady growth as he gains experience in both school and regional competitions. He is widely regarded as one of the rising talents in Western Province chess.

title: Bernard Dubbeld
content:
Bernard Dubbeld is a South African chess player who returned to competitive play in 2024, taking part in several tournaments in Cape Town and contributing actively in the local club league.
As a junior, Bernard represented KwaZulu-Natal Schools in 1994 and 1995, and later the KwaZulu-Natal Under-20 team at the South African Junior Chess Championship in 1997. These early experiences gave him a strong grounding in competitive play and interprovincial team events.
After a long break from the game, his return highlights both his commitment to the sport and his ability to compete steadily under tournament conditions. Today, Bernard continues to participate in local competitions, bringing with him the experience of his youth and the perspective of a seasoned player.

title: Callum Lau
content: Callum Lau is an emerging talent in Cape Town and active member of Steinitz Chess Club. In 2025 Callum achieved 3rd Place in the Western Cape Schools Chess High School Individual Provincial Championship, Representing Rondebosch Boys’ High School. His outstanding performance among the province’s top young chess talents earned him a coveted spot at the National Championships, where he will represent the Western Cape at the highest level of school chess competition in South Africa.

title: Chris Cronje
content: Chris Cronje spent countless weekends in tournament halls a decade ago as a dedicated chess parent, supporting his son Christiaan through the U8 and U10 circuits alongside fellow member Colin Webber. Now, with Christiaan back at the board, Chris has also rejoined the game—this time not just as a parent on the sidelines, but as a player in his own right.

title: Christiaan Cronje
content: Christiaan Cronje first made his mark in chess as an energetic U8 and U10 player, often competing alongside Ethan Webber in junior events. After stepping away from the game for several years, he has now returned to the board as a young adult—this time sharing the chess journey with his father, Chris, who first taught him the game.

title: Clinton Solomon
content:
Clinton Solomon is a passionate chess organizer, mentor, and advocate for youth chess in Cape Town. As the Youth Director of Steinitz Chess Club, he works tirelessly to create opportunities for young players, providing access to quality coaching, structured tournaments, and a supportive community. Since 2019, Clinton has traveled extensively across South Africa with his son, Izaiah Solomon—one of the region’s most promising young chess talents—attending both Federation and school chess tournaments. These experiences have given him a deep understanding of the needs and challenges facing youth chess players.
Beyond Steinitz, Clinton contributes to the broader chess community, serving on the District East Schools Executive since 2022 and the Cape Town Chess Youth Commission since 2023. A dedicated chess parent and advocate, he is committed to promoting the sport, nurturing talent, and helping children develop confidence, discipline, and creativity through chess. Through his leadership, Clinton continues to strengthen Steinitz’s reputation as a club that invests in its youth and fosters both competitive excellence and a lifelong love of the game.

title: Clinton Solomon
content:

title: Colin Webber
content: Colin Webber is an active member of the Cape Town chess community, balancing his own journey as an “adult improver” with his passion for supporting the game. A former chess parent—his son Ethan no longer plays competitively—Colin has stayed deeply connected to the sport through both playing and service. He currently serves as the Technical Officer and Webmaster of Steinitz Chess Club, where he helps manage the club’s digital presence and supports its ongoing growth. Alongside his technical contributions, Colin enjoys encouraging and mentoring young players, drawing on his experiences as both a parent and competitor. His enthusiasm for lifelong learning and his commitment to fostering talent make him a valuable part of the Steinitz family.

title: Colin Webber
content: Colin Webber is an active member of the Cape Town chess community, balancing his own journey as an “adult improver” with his passion for supporting the game. A former chess parent—his son Ethan no longer plays competitively—Colin has stayed deeply connected to the sport through both playing and service. Alongside his technical contributions, Colin enjoys encouraging and mentoring young players, drawing on his experiences as both a parent and competitor. His enthusiasm for lifelong learning and his commitment to fostering talent make him a valuable part of the Steinitz family.

title: Curtis Gal
content: Curtis Gal discovered chess in primary school and quickly developed a passion for the game. He dreams of one day becoming a Grandmaster and is working hard to achieve this goal in the shortest possible time. One of his proudest achievements so far has been representing the West Coast region. In 2024, Curtis chose Steinitz as his first club, drawn by its strong reputation and sense of camaraderie.

title: Declan Platen
content: Declan Platen is a respected player, coach, and leader within the Steinitz Chess Club, where he currently serves as Club Captain. Known for his steady play and deep understanding of the game, Declan has represented Steinitz in league competitions and other events, contributing both on and off the board. As a coach, he is dedicated to nurturing young talent, sharing his knowledge and experience to help players sharpen their skills and build confidence. His approachable teaching style and passion for chess make him a role model for many up-and-coming players in the Western Cape. In his role as Club Captain, Declan fosters team spirit and ensures that Steinitz continues its proud tradition of excellence and camaraderie. Balancing competitive play with mentorship, he exemplifies the values of leadership, sportsmanship, and commitment to the growth of chess in his community.

title: Declan Platen
content: Declan Platen is a respected player, coach, and leader within the Steinitz Chess Club, where he currently serves as Club Captain. Known for his steady play and deep understanding of the game, Declan has represented Steinitz in league competitions and other events, contributing both on and off the board. Balancing competitive play with mentorship, he exemplifies the values of leadership, sportsmanship, and commitment to the growth of chess in his community.

title: Donovan Allies
content: Donovan Allies is a committed and longstanding figure in Cape Town’s chess community, known for both his playing strength and his dedication to the development of the game. Over the years, he has competed in numerous league and open tournaments, consistently bringing determination and fighting spirit to the board. Donovan has represented his club with distinction, contributing to team successes in the fiercely competitive Western Province Chess League. Beyond his individual play, he is admired for his sportsmanship and his willingness to share knowledge and inspire others—particularly younger players making their way in the chess world. His passion for chess extends beyond competition, as he actively supports initiatives that promote the game at grassroots level. Through his steady presence and commitment, Donovan Allies continues to embody the values of discipline, resilience, and community that define the best of South African chess.

You can use this heading by the following markdown rules. For example: use # for heading 1 and use ###### for heading 6.
Heading 1 Heading 2 Heading 3 Heading 4 Heading 5 Heading 6 Emphasis The emphasis, aka italics, with asterisks or underscores.
Strong emphasis, aka bold, with asterisks or underscores.
The combined emphasis with asterisks and underscores.
Strike through uses two tildes. Scratch this.
Button Button Link I’m an inline-style link
I’m an inline-style link with title
I’m a reference-style link
I’m a relative reference to a repository file
You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions
Or leave it empty and use the link text itself.
URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or http://www.example.com and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, for example).

title: Ethan Samuels
content:
Ethan Samuels is an accomplished young adult chess player and coach from Cape Town, South Africa. Known for his sharp tactical awareness and steady positional play, he has developed a strong reputation both over the board and as a mentor to aspiring players. Ethan has represented his club and province in numerous competitions, consistently achieving notable results and establishing himself as one of the promising young figures in the South African chess scene.
Beyond his personal achievements, Ethan is passionate about sharing his knowledge and experience with others. As a coach, he works with players of varying ages and skill levels, focusing on building a solid foundation while encouraging creativity and confidence in their play. His patient and motivating teaching style has helped many of his students make rapid progress, both in competitive chess and in developing broader problem-solving skills.
Dedicated to growing the game in Cape Town, Ethan continues to balance his competitive ambitions with his commitment to teaching, inspiring the next generation of chess players to pursue excellence on and off the board.

title: Furqaan Bowman
content: Furqaan Bowman is a dedicated youth chess player whose journey reflects both talent and resilience. His strongest performance came during the Junior League U16, where he achieved a tournament performance rating of 1630 — a clear sign of his ability to compete at a high level when focused and motivated. Like many young players, Furqaan has taken time away from the board, but his passion for the game remains undimmed. He enjoys the challenge chess brings, testing his creativity, focus, and problem-solving under pressure. Known for his calm presence and thoughtful approach to the game, Furqaan brings a maturity to the board that belies his years. As he continues his chess journey, Furqaan is looking to build on past achievements and rediscover his competitive rhythm. His return to active play signals not only unfinished business but also the promise of future growth in the sport he loves.

title: Glenn Willenberg
content: Glen I. Willenberg is a seasoned chess player and life-long member of Steinitz Chess Club. Throughout his chess career, Glen has participated in various tournaments, including the South African Closed Chess Championship 2024, where he competed in the Seniors category . Beyond individual competitions, Glen is actively involved in the chess community. As of 2025 he proudly represents his club A-team at the CTCF club league. Glen’s dedication to chess and his active participation in both competitive and community events highlight his commitment to the game and its development in South Africa.

title: Ivan Fortune
content: Ivan Fortune has been a familiar face at the Steinitz Chess Club in Cape Town for decades. Though not known for chasing trophies or headline-making victories, his contribution to the club runs much deeper than tournament results. Ivan embodies the quiet commitment that has kept the Steinitz community thriving over the years. Year after year, he has been there at the club’s meetings and tournaments, ready to take on anyone across the board, whether it’s a seasoned veteran or a newcomer still finding their way. His steady presence has given many players—young and old alike—a sense of continuity and welcome. Those who know him often remark on his sportsmanship and the easygoing spirit he brings to both friendly games and more competitive encounters. For Ivan, chess has always been as much about the people as the pieces. His long membership at Steinitz speaks not only to a love of the game but also to a belief in the value of belonging to a community. In this way, he has become part of the club’s living history, a reminder that chess is sustained not only by champions but also by the loyal players who keep the boards and clocks in constant use.

title: Izaiah Solomon
content: Izaiah Solomon is a talented young chess player from South Africa, currently a Grade 10 learner at Curro Somerset West. He has demonstrated exceptional skill and leadership in the chess community. Achievements: Provincial Representation: In September 2025, Izaiah was selected to represent the Western Cape Boys Under-18 team at the Mzansi Interprovincial Youth Chess Championships (MIYCC), showcasing his prowess at the provincial level. Club Championship Success: In 2024, as a Grade 9 learner, Izaiah earned a silver medal at the Western Cape Club Championship, highlighting his competitive edge in regional tournaments. Team Leadership: Serving as captain, Izaiah led the Steinitz Chess Club’s Under-18 team to victory in the Cape Town Junior Chess League’s A Division in 2024, underscoring his leadership and teamwork abilities. Regional Championship Victory: In 2025, he won the inaugural Overberg Schools Chess Championship (OSAJCCC), demonstrating his dominance in regional competitions.

title: Jesse Palmer
content: Jesse Palmer is a promising young chess talent from Cape Town, South Africa. He holds the title of Arena International Master (AIM) and has achieved impressive FIDE ratings across all formats. Since 2024 he has since demonstrated remarkable improvement. He has participated in numerous tournaments, consistently achieving strong results. For instance, in the 2025 Bellville Rapid Tournament, he scored 6 points out of 6, showcasing his dominance in the rapid format. Beyond his individual accomplishments, Jesse is an active member of the chess community. He has represented his school, Curro Durbanville, in various competitions, contributing to their success. His dedication to the game and rapid progression have made him a notable figure among his peers.

title: Jody Roman
content: Jody Roman has always had a passion for chess. Through a chance interaction with one of Steinitz’s long-standing members, he was reintroduced to the game and welcomed into the close-knit Steinitz family. As a social player and adult improver, Jody has been eager to contribute—taking on the role of Team Captain for various development teams, competing more actively in local tournaments, and even stepping into an ExCo position at the club. Reflecting on his journey, Jody lives by the words of Wilhelm Steinitz: “Chess is not for timid souls.” The game brings both highs and lows, but for him, it is about taking the bull by the horns and enjoying the ride.

title: Jody Roman

Reflecting on his journey, Jody lives by the words of Wilhelm Steinitz: “Chess is not for timid souls.” The game brings both highs and lows, but for him, it is about taking the bull by the horns and enjoying the ride.

title: Jordan Adriaanse
content:
Jordan Adriaanse is a dedicated youth chess player and an active member of the Steinitz Chess Club. He has distinguished himself through both provincial representation and consistent club participation.
Key Achievements
Western Province Colours: Selected for the Western Province provincial team in his age group, earning the prestigious colours for chess.
Top Schools Tournament: Represented his school’s A-team at the Top Schools chess tournament, competing against the strongest teams in the region.
Club League Participation: A loyal and regular participant in the Steinitz Chess Club league, alternating between the D and C teams, contributing to team success and fostering club spirit.
Profile Summary
Jordan’s achievements highlight a balance of individual talent and team commitment. His experience at provincial, school, and club levels reflects his dedication to chess and his growing reputation as a reliable and skilled youth player in the Western Cape chess community.chievements highlight his growth as a strategic thinker and a competitive player. His dedication to both school and chess sets him apart as a rising talent in youth chess circles, with a foundation poised for continued success in regional and national tournaments.

title: Kenneth Willenberg
content: Kenneth Sean “Kenny” Willenberg is a South African Candidate Master (CM), currently regarded as one of the country’s strongest players. A product of Steinitz Chess Club and the proud Willenberg chess-playing legacy, Kenny has built a reputation for consistent success in both national closed championships and local league competitions. Once crowned South African Under-20 Champion, he has made multiple appearances at the SA Closed Championship, firmly establishing himself as one of the nation’s leading players early in his career. Beyond his own competitive achievements, Kenny has dedicated himself to coaching and talent development, working through programs at Curro Durbanville and Reddam House Durbanville. He was the originator of the Curro Cup, South Africa’s first online schools chess tournament, which has since grown into a landmark event on the scholastic calendar. His impact as a coach was most prominently seen at the 2025 Top Schools competition, where his Reddam U9 team not only placed first in their division but also swept all six board prizes—a rare and dominant feat. Balancing competitive strength with a passion for mentorship, Kenny continues to inspire both on and off the board, making him a highly respected figure in South African chess.

title: Liam Scott
content:
William Scott, known to friends and teammates as Liam, is a rising talent in the Steinitz Chess Club’s junior program. From a young age, Liam has demonstrated a natural aptitude for chess, combining sharp calculation skills with creative strategy.
A regular participant in local and regional tournaments, Liam has quickly earned a reputation for his calm composure under pressure and his ability to outthink opponents of all ages. His dedication to improvement is evident both in his careful study of classic games and his active participation in club training sessions.
Liam’s favorite openings reflect his dynamic style: he enjoys playing the Sicilian Defense as Black and the Queen’s Gambit as White, often surprising opponents with inventive middlegame ideas. Beyond his competitive play, he is known for supporting fellow juniors, sharing insights, and fostering a collaborative learning environment at Steinitz.
With a combination of talent, discipline, and a love for the game, Liam Scott is one of the most promising young players to watch in South Africa’s junior chess scene.

title: Lucy Khuphwathea
content:
Lucy Khuphwathea is a promising junior chess player from the Steinitz Chess Club and the eldest daughter of CM Paul Khuphwathea, a well respected coach hailing from Malawi.
In 2025, Lucy placed 2nd at the Central District tournament, demonstrating her competitive edge among a very strong field. She followed this up at the Western Cape High Schools Individuals in Vredenburg, where she posted an 80% win-rate, showing strong consistency and resilience under pressure. Lucy’s performances have earned her a place representing the Western Cape Under-16 team in the 2025 Mzansi Interprovincial Tournament, marking an important step in her chess career as she moves into larger provincial and national-level events. With the mentoring of her father and support from Steinitz, Lucy is developing a style grounded in disciplined play, tactical sharpness, and steady growth. She’s one to watch in youth chess in the Western Cape and beyond.

title: Lyndon Bouah
content: Dr. Lyndon Bouah is a distinguished figure in South African chess—both as a competitive veteran and as a scholar-administrator. Holding the title of Candidate Master, he has represented his nation at events including the 1992 and 1994 Chess Olympiads. In 2024, Bouah made a remarkable return to competitive play, emerging as co-champion in the Senior Section of the South African Closed Chess Championship, achieving an undefeated 8.5/11 alongside Dr. Shabier Bhawoodien. Off the board, Dr. Bouah is a committed researcher and author, notably publishing Reflection on Chess in the Rainbow Nation, a deeply personal and cultural exploration of chess in South Africa. He also serves as the Chief Director for Sport and Recreation in the Western Cape, blending his passion for chess with leadership in public service.

title: Mark Lewis
content: Mark Lewis is a seasoned chess coach and a founding member of Cape Town’s Steinitz Chess Club, established in 1976 when four high-school students in Bonteheuwel came together to form a club named after World Champion Wilhelm Steinitz. A respected leader in South African chess, Lewis is a former president of both the Steinitz Chess Club and the Cape Town Chess Federation (CTCF). Under his leadership, Steinitz grew into one of the strongest clubs in the country, winning national titles and nurturing top players from the Cape Flats. In addition to his administrative and coaching roles, Lewis remains active as a competitive player, highlighted by his victory at the 2022 South African Senior Championship, scoring 7.5 points. His lifelong dedication has left a lasting mark on South African chess.

title: Mark Lewis
content: Mark Lewis is a seasoned chess coach and a founding member of Cape Town’s Steinitz Chess Club, established in 1976 when four high-school students in Bonteheuwel came together to form a club named after World Champion Wilhelm Steinitz. In addition to his administrative and coaching roles, Lewis remains active as a competitive player, highlighted by his victory at the 2022 South African Senior Championship, scoring 7.5 points. His lifelong dedication has left a lasting mark on South African chess.

title: Paul Khuphwathea
content: Paul C. Khuphwathea is a highly respected chess player and coach from Malawi, now making his mark in Cape Town, South Africa. A Candidate Master since 2016, he has represented his country with pride on the international stage, including appearances at the 2012 Chess Olympiad in Istanbul, Turkey, and again at the 42nd Olympiad in Baku, Azerbaijan, in 2016, where he faced some of the world’s strongest players. Beyond his own competitive success, Paul has devoted himself to the growth and development of young chess talent. A licensed FIDE Developmental Instructor (2011–2025), he now coaches full time at United Herzlia Schools and the German International School of Cape Town. His dynamic teaching style and deep love for the game have inspired countless students, helping them build not only chess skills but also confidence, discipline, and critical thinking. With his combination of international experience, coaching expertise, and passion for education, Paul continues to play a vital role in strengthening the chess culture of Cape Town and beyond.

title: Paul Khuphwathea
content: Paul C. Khuphwathea is a highly respected chess player and coach from Malawi, now making his mark in Cape Town, South Africa. A Candidate Master since 2016, he has represented his country with pride on the international stage, including appearances at the 2012 Chess Olympiad in Istanbul, Turkey, and again at the 42nd Olympiad in Baku, Azerbaijan, in 2016, where he faced some of the world’s strongest players. title: Paul Vorster
content: Paul Vorster is a talented young chess player and active participant at individual and team competitions. In February 2025, Paul achieved a notable second-place finish in the Advanced Section of the Cape of Good Hope Open 2025, a prestigious tournament in the Western Cape. He also represented his school, Stellenberg High School, in the Cape Town Metro Schools Chess Team, highlighting his active involvement in regional chess activities. Paul’s dedication to chess is further evident from his inclusion in the Western Province U16 Open Trials in 2022, indicating his early promise and commitment to the game.

title: Phillip Tjale
content:
A Chess Journey Phillipmaite Tjale learned how to play chess on a home-made set, much like the great Mikhail Botvinnik. This unique start sparked a deep appreciation for the Soviet-era chess players and a love for dynamic, attacking styles, with solid positional foundations. While his passion lies in aggressive play, his style is more a testament to the fundamentals: a solid, balanced approach that focuses on defensive soundness and capitalizing on his opponent’s errors.
A Return to the Board After a decade-long hiatus, he has returned to competitive chess with renewed purpose and a goal to regain and surpass his previous form. His early competitive experience was limited due to a lack of rated tournaments in his home province, but he did have the opportunity to participate in a number of events, including USSA tournaments, provincial tournaments, and the National Club Chess Tournament, where the team he led achieved a podium finish in one of the sections in 2013.
His first live encounter with Steinitz Chess Club was at that very tournament, and their passion and dominance left a lasting impression. When the opportunity arose to join, he didn’t hesitate. He is now actively working to improve his rating whilst enjoying the journey. The signs are encouraging; he is starting to recognize familiar patterns and regain his confidence. His ultimate aim is to play with a dynamic and free-flowing style, a goal he is confident he will reach in time

title: Pierre Goosen
content:
Pierre Goosen is a South African chess player who in recent years relocated to Cape Town and became a valued member of the Steinitz Chess Club. His decision to join Steinitz came naturally: when he mentioned his move to a colleague, he was told without hesitation that Steinitz is the best club in the country — advice he gladly took to heart.
Pierre brings a wealth of experience to the board, with a style defined by steady effort and persistence. He tends to play solidly, favouring classical time controls and engaging in well-balanced games that reflect his thoughtful approach to the sport. Among his notable achievements is finishing as runner-up among seniors in the B-division at the 2019 South African Open, a result that underscored both his consistency and his competitive spirit.
Beyond his own play, Pierre has also contributed to the local chess community in organisational roles. He briefly served as Treasurer for Chess Western Province, now known as the Cape Town Chess Federation, before stepping away from that position. His blend of over-the-board experience and community involvement makes him a respected figure within the Cape Town chess scene.

title: Privacy
description: How Steinitz Chess Club handles your privacy
content:
Privacy Policy At Steinitz Chess Club, we’re not just about chess — we’re about people. That means we respect your privacy and take care to protect any personal information you share with us. This policy explains, in plain language, what we collect, why we collect it, and how you stay in control.
At a Glance We only collect information we genuinely need to run the club. We use your details to manage memberships, tournaments, and communication. We never sell your information. We only share with trusted chess bodies (like Chess South Africa or FIDE) when necessary. You always have the right to see, update, or ask us to delete your information. 1. What Information We Collect When you join or take part in our activities, we may collect things like:
Your name and contact details (so we can keep in touch). Your membership and payment records. Chess activity – game results, ratings, and tournament participation. Limited website usage information (cookies or IP address) if you visit our site. 2. Why We Collect It We use this information to:
Keep our membership records up to date. Let you know about events, tournaments, and club news. Register you for competitions and report results to official chess federations. Improve the way our website and club services work. Meet any legal or regulatory requirements. 3. Who We Share With Your details stay within the club unless we need to:
Send results or ratings to chess bodies (Chess South Africa, FIDE). Use service providers who help us with payments, emails, or website hosting. Comply with the law. We will never sell your information or use it for marketing unrelated to the club.
4. How We Protect Your Information We use reasonable safeguards to protect your data from loss or misuse. While no system is 100% secure, we do our best to keep your information safe.
5. Your Rights (Under POPIA) Because we operate in South Africa, your rights are protected by the Protection of Personal Information Act (POPIA). You may:
Ask to see the information we hold about you. Request corrections if something is wrong. Ask us to delete your information (unless we must keep it for legal reasons). Withdraw your consent at any time. 6. Cookies and Website If our website uses cookies, they are just to make the site run better or understand how it’s being used. You can switch them off in your browser if you prefer.
7. How Long We Keep Information We keep your information only as long as it’s needed for membership, events, or legal purposes. After that, it’s securely deleted.
8. Changes to This Policy From time to time, we may update this policy. We’ll always post the latest version on our website.
9. Contact Us If you ever have questions about your privacy, please get in touch via our contact form:
Contact Form

title: Ready to build your next project with Hugo?
description: Experience the future of web development with Hugoplate and Hugo. Build lightning-fast static sites with ease and flexibility.

title: Reegan Palmer
content:
Reegan Palmer is a rising chess star from Cape Town, South Africa, celebrated for his sharp tactical acumen and strategic depth. In 2025, he secured a remarkable 7 points out of 9 in the South African Junior Closed Chess Championship (U18 Open), sharing the top spot with Lin Chenyi and earning a FIDE rating performance of 1791 . This performance underscores his prowess in the national chess arena.
As a Candidate Master (CM) since 2023, Reegan has consistently demonstrated his skill and dedication to the game. His journey includes triumphs such as winning the Western Province Chess Championship in 2023 and a strong showing at the 2025 South African Open Championship, where he competed against seasoned players .
Beyond his personal achievements, Reegan is committed to fostering the growth of chess in his community. He actively mentors younger players and participates in various chess initiatives, aiming to inspire the next generation of chess enthusiasts.

title: Richard Korebrits
content: Richard Korebrits has been a long-standing member of Steinitz and an avid participant in individual as well as team-based tournaments. He first showed his fighting spirit during a pivitol team match at the Eden Championship in the garden route. Since then he has gained strength consistently and can always be counted upon to represent his club when it matters most. On a personal note, he does not have children but does have pets. One of them is a Siamese cat named Chess, after Alexander Alekhine’s famous cat by the same name.

title: Roland Willenberg
content: Roland Willenberg is a veteran South African chess coach and one of the founding members of Steinitz. As a trailblazer in coaching, he was recognized as Cape Town’s first professional chess coach. Roland is also known as the father and early mentor of his sons, Kenny and Craig, both former junior South African champions. His contributions to South African chess—through community building, mentorship, and fostering talent—cement his reputation as a key figure in nurturing chess culture on the Cape Flats.

title: Roland Willenberg
content: Roland Willenberg is a veteran South African chess coach and one of the founding members of Steinitz. As a trailblazer in coaching, he was recognized as Cape Town’s first professional chess coach. Roland is also known as the father and early mentor of his sons, Kenny and Craig, both former junior South African champions. His contributions to South African chess—through community building, mentorship, and fostering talent—cement his reputation as a key figure in nurturing chess culture on the Cape Flats.

title: Romayo Page
content: Romayo Page’s journey in chess is a testament to dedication, mentorship, and community spirit. From the early days of competing with Boland A and B teams during the 1990s—sharing the stage with renowned players like Deon Pick and Kenny Solomon—Romayo’s love for the game was evident. Guided by the late Mr. Brown, a multifaceted mentor whose talents spanned authorship, songwriting, and chess, Romayo’s passion for the sport grew deeper with each passing year. As a leader, Romayo left a lasting mark on Western Cape Chess. Serving as Western Province Manager for Top Schools from 2009 to 2015, Romayo orchestrated a golden era for The Settlers High School Chess teams, who remained unbeaten for nine consecutive years—a feat made possible by the unwavering commitment of Steinitz coaches and a thriving school spirit. Romayo’s connection to the Willenberg family during his teaching tenure at The Settlers High School proved pivotal. This bond naturally led Romayo to join Steinitz Chess Club, where the sense of family and shared ambition continued to flourish. Throughout his career, Romayo Page has not only achieved personal success on the chessboard but has also inspired a generation of young players and fostered a vibrant chess community—demonstrating that, in chess as in life, it takes a village to nurture greatness.

title: Shaqeel Petersen-Bizaare
content: Shaqeel has been an active member of the Insight Chess Academy, run by Steinitz president Andrew Talmarkes. He represented the academy in the Under-17 Mixed category, where his team secured 3rd place . Additionally, he was recognized for his excellence in chess during his Grade 10 year at Protea Heights Academy, achieving 1st place in the school’s chess rankings. Recently he guided his school team to a podium finish at the Top Schools competition. Shaqeel’s involvement in both individual and team events reflects his dedication to the game and his potential for future growth in the chess community.

title: Shaun Willenberg
content: Shaun Willenberg is a founding member of the Steinitz Chess Club in Cape Town, established in 1976. The club was formed by four high-school students in the Kalksteensfontein area of Bonteheuwel, who named it after the first recognised chess world champion, Austrian Wilhelm Steinitz. Shaun has been actively involved in the club’s activities over the years. In the 2020 Steinitz Chess Festival, he was among the top performers, finishing on tiebreak in a five-way tie for first place. Shaun’s contributions have been instrumental in the club’s development and success, reflecting his dedication to promoting chess in the Cape Flats community.

title: Shaun Willenberg
content: Shaun Willenberg is a founding member of the Steinitz Chess Club in Cape Town, established in 1976. The club was formed by four high-school students in the Kalksteensfontein area of Bonteheuwel, who named it after the first recognised chess world champion, Austrian Wilhelm Steinitz. Shaun’s contributions have been instrumental in the club’s development and success, reflecting his dedication to promoting chess in the Cape Flats community.

title: Shaurya Singh
content: Shaurya Singh is a rising talent in South African chess and a dedicated member of the Steinitz Chess Club in Cape Town. Representing the Western Cape, he has delivered consistently strong performances at both regional and national level events. In 2023, he achieved a notable victory in the Intermediate section of the Western Cape Women’s Championship in Langebaan, while still in primary school, signaling his early promise. The same year, he went on to win the Western Cape Individual School Chess Tournament. Shaurya has since continued to distinguish himself in national competitions. At the 2025 South African Junior Closed Chess Championship (U14 Open), he scored 7 points out of 9, finishing in 3rd place. He has also competed in other high-level events such as the Moja Chess Extravaganza and the Cape Town Masters, further cementing his reputation as one of the Western Cape’s strongest junior players. Beyond results, Shaurya is an active and enthusiastic participant in the local chess scene. His dedication to continuous improvement and his growing track record of tournament success make him one of the promising young players to watch in South African chess.

title: Sophia Hagen
content:
Sophia Hagen is an emerging chess talent from Cape Town, South Africa, born in 2012. As of September 2025, she holds a FIDE ID of 14378558, reflecting her affiliation with the South African Chess Federation. International Chess Federation (FIDE)
🏆 Notable Achievements
Top 10 Ranking in Cape Town Youth Chess (Under 14): Sophia was ranked among the top 10 youth players in Cape Town as of January 2025, showcasing her competitive edge in the local chess scene. Participation in the Mzansi Interprovincial Chess Tournament: She represented her school, Laerskool Courtrai, in this prestigious tournament, further solidifying her reputation as a rising star in South African youth chess. Selection for the 2025 South African Junior Chess Championships: Sophia’s performance in the Mzansi Interprovincial Chess Tournament earned her a spot in the 2025 South African Junior Chess Championships, where she competed against some of the country’s top young players.

title: Triston Willenberg
content: Triston Willenberg is a South African chess player in his early twenties, representing the Steinitz Chess Club. A steady presence on the competitive circuit, he is known for his resilience and consistency in play, maintaining steady progress in his results over recent years. He tends to play solidly, often choosing classical time controls and engaging in well-balanced games, showing patience and composure against a wide range of opponents. As part of the younger generation of South African players, Triston continues to build his experience and reputation, contributing to both his club and the broader chess community.

title: Waynika Caeser
content:
Waynika Caeser discovered chess just three years ago and has quickly established herself as a rising talent in the Western Cape schools circuit. Her competitive journey began at the District East Trials, where she made an immediate impression by finishing 3rd in the combined U17 and U19 girls’ section.
In 2024, Waynika continued her strong progress, taking 2nd place in the Cape Town Metro Schools U19 Girls Division. She then went on to compete in the prestigious Western Cape Individual Championships, where she secured a 5th-place finish. This performance earned her qualification to represent the Western Cape at the Mzansi Inter-Regionals—an important milestone in her developing chess career.
With her determination, steady improvement, and proven results against tough competition, Waynika is a player to watch as she continues to build her presence in South African chess.

title: What people Are Saying About Steinitz Chess Club
description: We are proud of our achievements and the people who have supported us.
